No, but I can see how you might grasp at that explanation, even though the video evidence falsifies it: it makes sense but does not happen to be correct. Recall that from the top you see the letter pressed from the top but you see the other letter from below during the spin. Thus there's a third factor. If you slow the youtube playback you can see a vibration blurring the o when you see the x, and visa versa, and you can see both x and o are otherwise about equally affected by the spin and rotation. This vibration is imparted by the snap, and the vibration moves back and forth from end to end of the tube, and the vibration blurs the letter on the end that is vibrating. The period of time for the vibration to move from end to end is a multiple of the period of the rotation, thus vibration and rotation of the tube are synced, because the impulse energy is simultaneous for both. If you press the x you impart the vibration to the other end for that instant while the x faces up beneath your finger, and thus the instants when the x end is not vibrating happen when the x is up, which of course are also the instants when the o is up for exactly the same duration but is vibrating. You will also notice that the end which is pressed (say X) gets lifted up a little bit.
That's because of the magnus effect. The lower part of tube of X end is actually moving faster than the upper part. So lower part drags more air along with it and creates a high pressure region below X end and thus gets lifted up. Same can be said about the other end which was not pressed ( O in this case). The top part of O end is moving faster than the lower part and it gets pressed down between of a high pressure region above the O end ( and of course you need some contact too because there is gravity.)

My hypothesis is by shorting the tube, the total circumference cover by the outer end would be relatively closer to the circumference cover by the inner end of the tube. (and that not assuming that the inner end is spinning on point) and hence harder to spot its symbol. Likewise, if the tube is extremely long the tendency of spotting the outer symbol is more frequent and almost definite as now the outer circumference would have been many times larger compared to the inner circumference covered by the inner end. But because the tube is a cylinder, the outer end would have to complete more rotations in order to totally cover its required travel distance and as such, its symbol will resurface more often!

Fascinating experiment and answer. But as a photographer, this raises another question for me. My understanding is that if one presses down on the X, you thereby instigate a combination of longitudinal and axial movement which results in movement of the tube, such that the X which is moving relatively slower, will be "perceivable" to human vision, as well as an inverse rate of turn and spin on the O which then moving faster, and is beyond human perception.

This must mean that when moving from the slow speed of point-X towards the fast speed of point-O, there is a point at which human vision loses the ability to perceive the shape of a marking on the moving object. 

In photography terms, it would be similar to if one were photographing a moving object, and at each pass using a longer and longer exposure duration, starting first with very rapid durations and then increasing the time. There comes a point in the progression where the rendered image changes from depicting the moving object as if it is "frozen" in motion, to showing "motion blur", to eventually reaching a point at which the moving object cannot even render its form onto the captured scene. In this regard it's probably truer to keep the shutter duration constant, but to increase the speed of the hypothetical moving object.

My question is therefore, does human vision work similarly to that of motion cameras which capture a series of chronological frames? And at which point does our human vision lose the ability to perceive this movement?

We've all seen video footage of how the propeller of an aeroplane, when starting up, seems to spin one way, then momentarily appear static (albeit blurred), then reverse direction. This is because of where the propeller blade is in each successive frame, and due to the fact that the accelerating spin rate eventually "synchronises" with the camera's frame rate, to create the static effect, and then accelerates further to break that effect and create the appearance of the propeller reversing its spin. And depending on the frame rate and the rate of spin of the prop, this can occur more than once. At some point the propeller might become "invisible" to the camera due to it's high speed - this depends on the shutter duration being used.

But, unless I'm mistaken, the same thing happens with human vision - just at different rates to those of most cameras, which typically shoot at 24-60 frames per second. 

So I guess my real questions are: if this is the case, and human vision does in fact work similarly to motion cameras which make use of a series of captured frames, what is the equivalent "frame rate" and shutter duration of (average) human vision? At what point do humans begin to perceive moving objects as "blurred", and at which point do we loose the ability to see them moving?

This has to do with the camera's shutter speed and how it syncs with the frequency of the X and O. As Derek explained, the O is moving faster around the circle and the X is moving slower. This means the O has a higher and different frequency than the X. Agreed? Now, the camera's sensor automatically increases shutter speed to compensate for increased light when you point the camera towards the sky. When you point the camera toward the ground, it is not as bright and it selects a slower shutter speed. Slower shutter speed shows you the X, higher shutter speed shows you the O. If Derek switched to manual shutter speed, he can force the shutter speed to show X instead of O when filming from below the glass. This effect is eliminated with the high-speed camera, which uses extremely high shutter speed and high frame rates to capture both the X and O on the same side of the tube.

The explanation for this is that the tube will be spinning around its own center axis (within the hole of the tube) while rotating around a vertical axis. The letter that you put your finger on when you spun the tube will be spinning in one direction and the tube itself will be rotating in an opposite direction. This will make the x look slower relative to the other letter, and easier for your eye to see than the other.
When you look at it from under the table, the opposite happens. The x will be spinning in one direction and the tube will be rotating in the same direction while the other letter will be doing the opposite.

The explanation'doesn't prove the phenomena. Fact is that both x and o appear at the same time, it is our eye's limitation that we cant see them together and directions of velocities are not the proof to it, though it is a part of the reasoning. The image we see persist for 1/25 of a second, due to persistence of vision. The x or y that we see is actually the appearance of the letter multiple times at the same location and same orientation of the tube. Because outer edge is covering a larger volume in space; the probability of that alphabet to orient at same position and location has increased. While the inner alphabet is covering smaller volume in space hence its probability to appear and disappear is .5 and deviates less from it. Hence if you close your eyes and spin it. Then open your eyes. There is a chance that you would see the inner alphabet once in 24 repetition of the experiment.

Also I think that the side that is touching the ground( or the opposite side from where you put your finger) has less energy and also a lot more friction causing it to allow you to only see the letter you put your finger on

But the side you put your finger on has more energy causing it to have more thrust up-wards (referring to your spinning disc on a pole video) which will cause it to go higher but it is on the outside which will make it in your view longer which will allow you to see that letter

The spin is divided into two components:

1) The tubular axis spin (parallel to the tube length)
2) The tube's principal axis spin (perpendicular to the area which the tube "sweeps")

As the tube sweeps due to its principal axis spin, its ends may:

1) Both be seen to be moving CW, or
2) Both be seen to be moving CCW.

....depending on what side you are looking at it from.

However, the tubular axis spin causes a different effect. In this case, labels on both ends are not affected in the same rotational direction, but rather, in the same translational direction....

Think of clock orientation. When the front side is viewed, which we will call the "front side view", notice how 9 o'clock is to the left and 3 o'clock is to the right.

Now imagine that the tube initially had its tubular spin axis aligned with the connect between 12 o'clock and 6 o'clock. Following the axial spin of this tube, we will call the "back side view" the view where the relative positions of 3 o'clock and 9 o'clock are swapped, while 12 o'clock and 6 o'clock are unswapped. Now that we defined both the front and back views of the clock, we note that if the tubular axis spin causes the labels to move from left to right on the front side, continuing the tubular axis spin will cause the labels to move from left to right on the back side as well. The results:

1) The label at 12 o'clock (call it Label X) is still moved in a clockwise direction by the tubular axis spin, regardless of which side we look from, and
2) The label at 6 o'clock (call it Label O) is still moved in a counter-clockwise direction by the tubular axis spin, regardless of which side we look from.

The rotational effect on each label caused by tubular axis spin is unaffected by what side we are looking at, but the effects for each label are opposite of each other (clockwise for Label X and counter-clockwise for Label O).

The rotational effect on each label caused by principal axis spin are both the same (clockwise), but when we look on the other side, we see that this effect has reversed (counter-clockwise).

If we take the scenario of the principal axis spin causing the tube to tilt the same way as the hands of a clock, then the combined result is that:

1) From the front side view, Label O (6 o'clock) is more visible than X (12 o'clock), as from this view the tubular axis spin makes Label O move from left to right, causing counter-clockwise motion with respect to the clockwise-tilting tube (retrograde motion).
2) From the back side view, Label X (12 o'clock) is more visible than O (6 o'clock), as from this view the tubular axis spin makes Label X move from left to right, causing clockwise motion with respect to the counter-clockwise-tilting tube (retrograde motion).

Now why then would the label that you put your finger on be the one that you can see better during the spin (i.e. the one with apparent retrograde motion)? The reason is that you are applying a torque which generates the both the tubular axis spin and the tube's principal axis spin simultaneously. When you push your finger on one end while retracting your finger, your push causes the end to slide against the surface of the table, while your retracting finger induces a roll which appears retrograde from the sliding motion that you are initiating. However, the movement of that label is only "retrograde" from that side, because, on the other side, the movement of the label on that same end you pushed on would instead be seen moving "prograde" with the principal spin and thus will be harder to see when you look from that side.

Actually, your eyes do have a frame rate. Granted, it varies with different factors, but there is a limit. This is caused by the physical speed limitations of signal (chemical and electrical) transmission.

This is why we see more in a slow-motion replay than we do when watching something live - because we see more frames than our eye naturally can. It's also why there is an optimum fps rate for animations. Beyond the optimum, you're wasting frames because people can't detect them.

Secondly you can do this same trick with any coin. Spin the coin on it's side. As the coin come to a stop it will have the same double-axis spin the tube does in this video. If you view the coin from above you will notice you can't see the bottom half of the coin. View from the side and you will see the edge of the coin more than the surface of the coin. It's a visual mind trick.
You would catch whichever end your focusing on more. The root to this trick is your brain filling in visual gaps. See the "STOPPED CLOCK ILLUSION" on Vsauce.

There is a much more basic "force" at work here. Yes, the tube is spinning on two axis, but that is not the reason why the second symbol dis-appears from view. As the tube spins our visual brain can't keep up the same way a slow motion camera can. To make up for this our brain tries to fill in the gaps. However since the upper radius is nearer to our visual input our brain will fill in with only the upper half. The reverse is true when viewed from below (the lower radius is closer).

An average humans Flicker Fusion Threshold (the point at which the flicker will no longer be perceived) is dependent on illumination.  At low illumination levels it is around 20Hz, while at high is around 60Hz.  30fps is perfectly adequate for film, as it is black between frames and most people will not perceive any flicker.  High sample rates in TVs exist to combat specific problems not directly caused by flicker, such as lack of saturation in plasma, or eye tracking motion blur in LCD.

@whiSSSper Because now you've reversed the rotation. Now it's the O that's rotating in the opposite direction of the spin of the tube.

If you look at the tube from above and see, say, the symbol spinning from left to right around the longitudinal axis, then seen from below it's spinning from right to left. Imagine the tube being transparent and picture the symbol revolving around the longitudinal axis as you look at it straight from the top. That's why you then don't see the symbol from below the glass table when you can see it from above.
